title: What can I do to start with music production at only 13? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here’s what you DON’T need to get into music production: Expensive equipmentComplicated softwareTalentYears of experienceTo start, make use of what you already have (which I assume is a smart phone or tablet). Download GarageBand if you have an iOS device and start there. You can actually do a lot with this simple app, more than what most people suggest. From there, you have two options: learn on your own or get help from an experienced instructor. I currently mentor young students on how to produce in GarageBand and I do so because I believe it’s the easiest, most intuitive, most fun way to get started in production. You can teach yourself, sure, but that takes months, sometimes years and the likelihood of failure is extremely high. If you’d like to be instantly boosted to an advanced level of producing relatively quickly and affordably, I’d consider my online course / mentor-ship. It provides a ton of value to people in your position. I’d love to help you! Regardless, GarageBand is my best recommendation on how to get started. My little brother can use it and he’s 12.

As those below have said, pretty much everything is open to you, but my guess is you have very little money, and feel like you don’t have much time, and want to know where to start. A few things that you can definitely do: If you have a computer, even a smartphone, you can get a DAW. There are plenty of free or near-free ones. They all have their quirks, but they can all be used to make music in some way.Work out the basics of the style of music you want to make. Let’s say you like modern EDM/Techno/Dubstep - try to make different kick drum and bass sounds. Like hip hop? Get some old drum breaks and work out how to use a sampler. Listen to the tunes you like and try to replicate their sounds.Listen to music you don’t like. Go out of your way to listen to music you don’t enjoy - whether it’s too sweet and simple, or weird and noisy and complex. Try to break the different parts up in your head, and work out why they’ve been put together that way. What parts of the sound come from which types of production? Now try to do the same with music you actually like.
